para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Adverse action” means any action taken by the DASO to deny, reduce, terminate, delay, or suspend a covered service.

“Aftercare” means the period of follow-up care after initial services are rendered, during which any additional related services rendered by the same provider are included in the payment for the original services.
“Ambulatory surgical center (ASC)” means any Medicare-certified entity that operates exclusively for the purpose of providing surgical services to patients not requiring hospitalization.
“Appeal” means the process:
To resolve a participant's dispute with any adverse action taken by the DASO to deny, reduce, terminate, delay, or suspend a covered service; and
Governed by:
COMAR 10.01.04; and
Any and all applicable court orders.
“Benefits” means a schedule of dental services to be administered by the DBA to Medical Assistance participants pursuant to this chapter.
“Brick and mortar dental office” means the fixed and permanent location where the mobile dental unit:
Is linked through either ownership or a legally binding contract; and
Transmits participant records.
“Claim” means an itemized statement requesting payment for services rendered by health care providers, such as dentists, billed:
Electronically;
Through a web-based portal; or
Manually on the American Dental Association (ADA) claim form.

“Consultation” means written opinion or advice rendered by a dentist, upon request by the patient's attending physician or dentist, for the further evaluation or management of the patient by the attending physician or dentist. If the consultant dentist assumes responsibility for the continuing care of the patient, a subsequent service rendered by the consultant is not a consultation.
“Dental Administrative Services Organization (DASO)” means an entity with which the Department contracts to administer dental benefits by performing some or all of the following functions:
General administration;
Regulatory compliance;
Network administration;
Member services;
Claims administration;
Data reporting and analysis;
Medical management; or
Quality monitoring.
“Dental services” means emergency, preventive, or therapeutic services for oral diseases which are administered by or under the general supervision of a dentist in the practice of the profession.

“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health, the single State agency designated to administer the Maryland Medical Assistance Program under Title XIX of the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. §§1396 et seq., or the Department's designee.
“Early and Periodic Screening, Diagnosis, and Treatment (EPSDT)” means comprehensive and preventive health care pursuant to 42 U.S.C. §1396d(e) as amended by OBRA 1989.

“Emergency services” means services necessary for the treatment of any condition requiring immediate attention for the relief of pain, hemorrhage, acute infection, or traumatic injury to the teeth, supporting structures (that is, periodontal membranes, gums, and alveolar bone), the jaws, and tissues of the oral cavity.
“EPSDT certified provider” means a physician, physician assistant, or nurse practitioner certified by the Department to provide EPSDT services.

“Free-standing clinic” means a health care facility approved for participation in the Maryland Medical Assistance Program that is not licensed as a hospital or as part of a hospital or nursing home and that is not administratively part of a health maintenance organization or physician's, dentist's, or osteopath's office, but which has a separate staff functioning under the direction of the clinic administrator (as defined in 42 CFR §405.1801) or a health officer and which is organized and operated to provide clinic services.
“General supervision” has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.44.21 and 10.44.27.
“Hospital” has the meaning stated in Health-General Article, Title 19, Subtitle 3, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program” means the Maryland Medicaid dental program.
“Medical Assistance Program” means the program of comprehensive medical and other health-related care for indigent and medically indigent persons.
“Medically necessary” means that a service or benefit is:
Directly related to diagnostic, preventive, curative, palliative, rehabilitative, or ameliorative treatment of an illness, injury, disability, or health condition;
Consistent with currently accepted standards of good medical practice, dental practice, or both;
The most cost effective service that can be provided without sacrificing effectiveness or access to care; and
Not primarily for the convenience of the consumer, family, or provider.
“Medicare” means the insurance program administered by the Federal government under Title XVIII of the Social Security Act, 42 U.S.C. §§1395 et seq.

“Mobile dental unit” means any self-contained facility in which dentistry will be provided and which may be moved, towed, or transported from one location to another to provide clinically necessary and appropriate dental care in the unit.

“Mobile dental practice” means any practice which provides the necessary and clinically appropriate dental equipment to be delivered to a community based location where dental services will be provided on site.
“Network provider” means a health care entity or health care professional that has executed a provider agreement with Maryland Medicaid.
“Participant” means an individual who is certified as eligible for, and is receiving, Medical Assistance benefits.
“Preauthorization” means an approval required from the Department or its designee before the provision of dental or oral health care services.
“Primary dental office” means the fixed and permanent location where the mobile dental unit:
Is linked through either ownership or a legally binding contract; and
Transmits participant records.
“Program” means the Maryland Medical Assistance Program.
“Provider” means:

An individual dentist, duly licensed to provide services for participants, or an association, partnership, or an incorporated or unincorporated group of dentists so licensed, that, through appropriate agreement with the Department, has been identified as a Program provider by the issuance of an individual account number; or

An approved dental school whose students are permitted under Health Occupations Article, §4-301(b)(1), Annotated Code of Maryland, to treat dental patients and which, through appropriate agreement with the Department, has been identified as a Program provider by issuance of an individual account number.

“Referral” means a transfer of the patient from a physician or dentist to a dentist for diagnosis and treatment of the condition for which the referral was made. The dentist to whom the referral is made will no longer be considered the consultant.
“REM” means the fee-for-service managed care program for individuals who have certain rare and expensive health care conditions set forth in COMAR 10.09.69.
“Self-ligating braces” means braces which utilize a permanently installed, moveable component to secure the archwire without the use of ligatures.

“Traditional comprehensive orthodontic treatment” means a coordinated diagnosis and treatment to improve craniofacial dysfunction or dentofacial deformity which may utilize fixed and removable orthodontic appliances and focus on specific objectives at various stages of dentofacial development.
The provider shall meet all license requirements as set forth in COMAR 10.09.36.02.
A dentist shall be licensed and legally authorized to practice dentistry in the state in which service is provided.
All dentists and dental hygienists working for a mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice shall be currently licensed and registered with the Maryland Board of Dental Examiners.
The driver of the mobile dental unit:
Shall possess a valid operator’s license appropriate for the type of vehicle that is driven;
May not have violations related to the operation of a motor vehicle in the last 3 years; and
May not have any violations involving alcohol or other illegal substances related to the operation of a motor vehicle in the last 10 years.
An EPSDT certified provider shall be:
A doctor of medicine licensed and legally authorized to practice in the state in which the service is provided;
A nurse practitioner who is licensed and certified to practice in the state in which services are provided;
A physician assistant who is licensed to practice in the state in which services are provided; or
A local health department, or a federally qualified health center, which has on its staff, and under whose supervision EPSDT services are delivered:
A doctor of medicine licensed in the state in which the service is provided;
A nurse practitioner licensed and certified in the state in which services are provided; or
A physician assistant licensed in the state in which services are provided.

The provider shall ensure that all X-ray or other radiological equipment is inspected and meets the standards established in COMAR 26.12.01 or other applicable standards established by the state in which the service is provided.
The provider shall ensure that Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) certification exists for all clinical laboratory services rendered, and:
If located in Maryland, comply with requirements of Health-General Article, Title 17, Subtitles 2 and 3, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.10.06; or
If located out-of-State, comply with other applicable standards established by the state or locality in which the service is provided.

section.heading: Provider Qualifications and Conditions for Participation.

para.text: General requirements for participation in the Program are that a provider shall:
Comply with requirements set forth in COMAR 10.09.36; and
If delivering services via telehealth, comply with COMAR 10.09.49 and any subregulatory guidance issued by the Department.
To participate in the Program as a dental provider, a provider shall meet the licensure requirements established in Regulation .02 of this chapter.
To participate in the Program as an EPSDT certified provider of fluoride varnish services, the provider shall:
Have MDH Certification for the Application of Fluoride Varnish; and
Meet the following requirements:
Be board-certified in one of the following:
Pediatrics;
Family practice; or
Internal medicine;
Be a licensed physician, physician assistant, or licensed and certified nurse practitioner, delivering primary health care to children and adolescents; or
Be a local health department or a federally qualified health center.
The provider shall:
Complete the Dental Provider Application; and
Submit verification of the National Provider Identifier (NPI) Number.
Mobile Dental Unit and Mobile Dental Practice.
The mobile dental unit shall provide or arrange for comprehensive dental services with a participating Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program provider.
The mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice shall be linked through either ownership or a legally binding contract to a brick and mortar dental office that has a permanent and fixed location.
The brick and mortar dental office shall participate in the Maryland Healthy Smiles Dental Program.
The mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice shall have and utilize the electronic technology that enables the same day exchange of patient records with:
The brick and mortar dental office; and
If requested, the dental office of the parent or legal guardian's choice.

The mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice service area shall be limited to 30 miles in a rural setting and 10 miles in an urban setting from the brick and mortar dental office that the mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice is either owned by or with which the dental office holds a legally binding contract.
A mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice shall:
Maintain dental records for the patient;
Observe all patient rights;
Obtain written, informed consent from a parent or legal guardian, which shall:
Be renewed each school year before treating a minor; and
Allow the parent or legal guardian to request that the dental records be sent to a provider of their choice;
Comply with all applicable federal, State, and local laws, regulations, and ordinances regulating:
Equipment;
Flammability;
Construction;
Infection control;
Sanitation procedures; and
Zoning;
Comply with the statutes and regulations of the Maryland Department of the Environment for all dental radiographic and imaging equipment;

Obtain, keep current, and make readily available all applicable county and city licenses or permits necessary to operate the mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice which would include the active dentist, hygienist and dental assistant licenses and the dental radiographic and imaging equipment permits;
Provide an update to the Department regarding any mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice provider changes within 72 hours;
Provide access to a ramp or a lift if services are provided to disabled individuals;
Have ready access to a properly functioning sterilization system;
Have ready access to an adequate supply of potable water, including hot water;
Have immediate access to toilet facilities;
Have an appropriately covered noncorrosive metal container for refuse and waste materials;
Have carbon monoxide and smoke detection devices or systems installed and in proper working condition;
Have a chair designed and purposed exclusively for the provision of dental services;
Have a dental treatment light;
Have a radiograph unit with appropriate processing equipment;
Have an evacuation unit suitable for dental surgical use;
Have written procedures for medical emergencies;
Have appropriate equipment to treat medical emergencies;
Have appropriate and sufficient dental instruments and infection control supplies; and
Have any other equipment or system that is necessary to provide the services being rendered by the mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice.
Dental hygienists or dental assistants may not solely operate a mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice.

The owner or owners of a mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice shall submit a business plan to the dental administrative service organization for the mobile unit or mobile dental practice that includes:
The mission of the mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice;
Verification of ownership of the mobile dental unit and mobile dental practice;
A list of the clinical practitioners that will render services in the mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice; and
The targeted population.

The Program covers medically necessary dental services for participants younger than 21 years old and eligible former foster care participants younger than 26 years old, including but not limited to the following:
Emergency, preventive, diagnostic, and treatment services;
Semiannual cleaning, fluoride treatment and examination;
Pit and fissure sealants for the occlusal surfaces of posterior permanent teeth that are without decay;
Orthodontic care for conditions which:
Have adjusted case scores of at least 15 points on the Handicapping Labio-Lingual Deviations Index (HLD) Table No. 4; and
Cause dysfunction due to a handicapping malocclusion that is supported by comprehensive pretreatment orthodontic records, which include at a minimum:
Cephalometric head film with analysis;
Panoramic or full series periapical radiographs;
Extra-oral and intra-oral photographs;
Clinical summary with diagnosis;
HLD score sheets from attending orthodontist; and
Treatment plan;
Consultations for participants who meet the requirements of §A(1), (2), (3), or (4) of this regulation;
Drugs dispensed or injectable drugs administered by the dentist within the limitations of COMAR 10.09.03;
Oral Health assessment by an EPSDT certified provider, and if determined medically necessary, the application of fluoride varnish for children 9 months old through 5 years old;
General anesthesia during dental procedures, when it is medically necessary; and
Fluoride varnish.
The Program covers the following medically necessary dental services for participants 21 years old or older:
Periodic, limited, and comprehensive oral examinations;
X-rays, including:
First and each additional intraoral periapical film;
Single, two, three, or four film bitewings, which are limited to:
Two per patient per year for REM participants 21 years old or older; or
One per patient per year for pregnant participants 21 years old or older; and
One panoramic radiographic image every 36 months;
Prophylaxis for adults, which is limited to:
One per patient per 3 months for REM participants 21 years old or older; or
Two per patient per 12 months for adults ages 21 and over;
Topical application of fluoride, which is limited to:
One application per patient per 6 months for REM participants 21 years old or older; or
One application per patient per year for pregnant and postpartum participants 21 years old or older;
Amalgam restorations for permanent teeth for one, two, three, four, or more surfaces, which are limited to one identical restoration per tooth per 24 months;
Resin restorations for anterior permanent teeth for one, two, three, four, or more surfaces or involving incisal angle, which are limited to one identical restoration per tooth per 24 months;
Other restorative services including:
Recementing of crowns, which is limited to two times for the same crown;
Prefabricated stainless steel crown for permanent teeth;
Fillings — sedative, interim or temporary filling; and
Pin retention — per tooth, in addition to restoration;
Pulp capping, direct and indirect, excluding final restoration;
Gingovectomy or gingivoplasty — per quadrant, which is limited to two quadrants per year per patient;
Periodontal scaling and root planning — per quadrant;
Full mouth debridement, which is limited to one per patient per 2 years, and may not be completed on the same day as prophylaxis;
Periodontal maintenance — following active periodontal therapy, which is limited to two per patient per year;
Adjustment of complete maxillary and mandibular denture;
Adjustment of partial maxillary and mandibular denture;
Recementing of bridge, which is limited to two times for the same bridge;
Extractions of:
Coronal remnants for deciduous teeth; and
Erupted tooth or exposed root;
Biopsy of oral tissue, hard or soft;
Alveoplasty, in conjunction or not in conjunction with extractions — per quadrant;
Incision and drainage of abscess intraoral; and
Palliative emergency treatment of dental pain that is not associated with recently rendered service.
The Program shall reimburse for covered services in §§A and B of this regulation if:
The services are rendered in:
The dentist's office;
The participant's home by an approved mobile dental unit;
A general acute hospital;
A skilled or intermediate care nursing facility;
A free-standing clinic;
An EPSDT certified provider's office;
An approved mobile dental unit or mobile dental practice;
A Medicare-certified ambulatory surgical center; or
Via telehealth in compliance with COMAR 10.09.49.
The services are provided by the dentist or one of the following:
Another licensed dentist enrolled with Medicaid in the dentist’s employ;
A dental hygienist or dental assistant, provided that the individual rendering the service is:
In the dentist's employ or in the employ of a public health program;
Under general supervision of a licensed dentist; and
Within the scope of the individual’s training or certification for the purpose of assisting in the provision of dental services; or
An EPSDT certified provider for the purpose of applying fluoride varnish;
The services are clearly related to the participant's individual dental care needs as ameliorative, diagnostic, curative, palliative, preventive, or rehabilitative services; and
The services are adequately described on the participant's dental care record in accordance with record-keeping practices detailed in COMAR 10.44.30.
The Program places the following limitations upon covered services:

Reimbursement for a complete radiographic survey or full series of X-rays of the mouth may not be made more frequently than once every 3 years to the same provider, or in the case of a group practice, to any partner or associate of that practice, unless medically necessary or specifically required or requested by the Program.

For any traumatic injury case, a provider may be reimbursed for a maximum of four panoramic or other extra-oral radiographs. When services are rendered by members of a group practice or association, reimbursement to the group practice or association shall also be limited to a maximum of four panoramic or other extra-oral radiographs.
Endodontic therapies and pulpectomies may not be covered when:
Root resorption has started and exfoliation is imminent;
Gross periapical or periodontal pathosis is demonstrated on the radiograph; or
The general oral condition does not justify endodontic therapy.

Reimbursement for crowns will be limited to permanent resin fused to metal crowns, permanent porcelain fused to metal crowns, permanent nonprecious metal (full cast), provisional resin crowns, prefabricated zirconia crowns, and stainless steel crowns.
Composite restorations will be covered for all teeth when necessary for the particular conditions of the patient.
Replacement dentures for participants who meet the requirements of Regulation .04A(3) of this chapter will be covered only when:
Dentures have been lost, broken, or stolen after 1 year of placement; or
Adjustment, repair, relining, or rebasing of the patient's present denture does not make it serviceable.
Rebasing is included in the 6 months of aftercare following denture placement, and may not be provided more frequently than once every 2 years after that.
Reimbursement for endodontic therapy includes all diagnostic tests, preoperative and postoperative radiographs, preoperative and postoperative treatments, pulpotomies and pulpectomies.
Reimbursement for a sinus closure will only be made when this service is rendered as a separate procedure and not in conjunction with the removal of a tooth.

Separate reimbursement will not be made for cavity liners and office visits, as these procedures are considered to be components of the necessary treatment. These services may not be billed to the participant.
The provider may bill for emergency treatment or for the actual dental procedures rendered during an emergency visit, but not for both.
Gold restorations, gold crowns, and gold replacement appliances are not covered services.
The Program's fee for a complete series of intra-oral radiographs including bitewings, represents the maximum payable for any combination of periapical X-rays and bitewings.
Assistant surgeons' services are covered only:
As specified in Regulation .07M of this chapter;
If the procedures were rendered in a hospital or a Medicare-certified ambulatory surgery center; and
If the assistant surgeon is a dentist.
The Program does not cover:
Fixed bridge work;
Cosmetic procedures;
Inpatient hospital dental or oral health care services rendered during an admission;
Services which are investigational or experimental;
Local anesthesia as a separate charge;
Duplication of dentures;
Drugs and supplies dispensed by the dentist which are acquired by the dentist at no cost;
Referrals;
Diagnostic models as a separate charge;
Office visits as a separate service;
Immediate dentures;

Consultant payments when a member of the house staff of a hospital either requests or provides the consultations or, in the case of a group practice, to any partner or associate of that practice who either requests or provides the consultation;
Aftercare services as a separate charge to a provider or, in the case of a group practice, to any partner or associate of that practice;
Services when reimbursement is included under another segment of the Program;
Unilateral partial dentures replacing fewer than three teeth, excluding third molars;
Implants;
More than one, per participant per lifetime, of the following services:
Traditional comprehensive orthodontic treatment; or
Self-ligating braces; and
Services rendered without the required preauthorization.
To obtain compensation from the Department for covered services, the provider shall submit a request for payment on the form designated by the Department with the following data or attachments:
If applicable, the preauthorization number shall be inserted in the designated appropriate field on the invoice claim form;
If applicable, pathology reports shall be attached to the claim form; and
If applicable, comprehensive narratives shall be attached to the claim form for those services that are "By Report".
The Department reserves the right to return to the provider, before payment, all invoices not properly signed or completed.

All prosthetic appliances shall be inserted in the mouth and adjusted before the Program is billed, except when the patient has expired, cannot be located, or refuses to return for completion of treatment. In these cases, the Department will reimburse the provider 80 percent of the maximum State fee for the procedure code for the laboratory bill only.
The provider shall charge the Program the provider's customary charge to the general public for similar services. If the service is free to individuals not covered by Medicaid:
The provider:
May charge the Program; and
Shall be reimbursed in accordance with §E of this regulation; and
The current Maryland Medicaid Dental Services Fee Schedule and Procedure Codes CDT is incorporated by reference, effective January 1, 2024.
The provider shall be paid the lesser of:
The provider's customary charge to the general public unless the service is free to individuals not covered by Medicaid; or
The rate in accordance with the Department's fee schedule.
The provider may not bill the Department or the participant for:
Completion of forms and reports;
Broken or missed appointments;
Professional services rendered by mail or telephone; or
Providing a copy of a participant's medical record when requested by another licensed provider on the participant's behalf.
Reimbursement for Traditional Comprehensive Orthodontic Treatment.
The Program shall reimburse for orthodontic treatment for a maximum of 24 periodic visits at an established rate, provided the treatment meets the standards established in COMAR 10.09.05.06F.
Orthodontic treatment is a once in a lifetime benefit.
Reimbursement for Self-Ligating Braces.
The Program shall reimburse for:
A pre-orthodontic visit;
Comprehensive orthodontia; and
A maximum of 12 periodic treatment visits at an established rate, provided the treatment meets the standards established in COMAR 10.09.05.06F.
When a claim is submitted to the Program for the banding of self-ligating braces, the following documentation shall be submitted with the claim:
A photograph of the recipient's oral cavity to confirm the placement of self-ligating braces; and
A statement signed by the parent or guardian of the child receiving treatment, acknowledging that:
Orthodontic services are a once in a lifetime benefit; and
The participant will not be able to pursue additional orthodontic services from the Medicaid Program at a later date.
The Department may not make direct payment to nurses, dental assistants, anesthetists, or dental hygienists.
The Department may not make direct payment to the participant.
Billing time limitations for claims submitted pursuant to this chapter are set forth in COMAR 10.09.36.06.

Those dental clinics licensed as part of a hospital in Maryland may charge and be reimbursed according to rates approved by the Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) pursuant to COMAR 10.37.03.

Payment for assistant surgeons' services is a maximum of 20 percent of the listed fee paid to the primary surgeon or the fee as determined by the Program for the treatment rendered. The minimum allowance is $25 or the dentist's charge, whichever is lower.
Providers may exercise appeal rights pursuant to State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The provider may appeal a decision to the Office of Administrative Hearings as specified in COMAR 10.09.36.09.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Active nursing practice” as used in Health Occupations Article, §8-312, Annotated Code of Maryland, means:
The practice of registered nursing or licensed practical nursing as defined in Health Occupations Article, §8-101, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Related nursing activities approved by the Board, including but not limited to a generic nursing education program, degree completion programs, or graduate programs within the last 5 years; and
Completion of a generic nursing education program, degree completion program, or a graduate program within the last 5 years.
“Advanced practice registered nurse” has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §8-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Biennial renewal” means renewal of a license every 2 years in the licensee’s birth month.
“Board” means the Maryland Board of Nursing.
“Central Repository” means the Maryland Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services.
Certified Nursing Assistant.
“Certified nursing assistant” means an individual, regardless of title, who routinely performs nursing tasks delegated by a registered nurse or licensed practice nurse for compensation.
“Certified nursing assistant” does not mean a certified medication technician.

“Continuing education” means planned, organized learning experiences designed to augment the knowledge, skill, and ability to enhance nursing practice and therefore improve health care delivered to the public.
“Continuing education unit (CEU)” means 1 contact hour of 50—60 minutes.
“Cosign” means a registered nurse verifies that:
An activity was performed safely and accurately by the nursing graduate; and
The documentation is complete and accurate.

“Criminal history records check” means the performance of both a State criminal history check by the Central Repository, and a national criminal history check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).

“Criminal history records information” means information provided by the criminal history records check regarding an applicant's criminal arrests, charges, and convictions, and other dispositions of criminal charges.

“Educational qualifications” means that at the time the applicant graduated from a registered nursing or licensed practical nursing education program, that program was substantially equivalent to the registered nursing or practical nursing education programs approved in this State.

“Endorsement” means, for qualified applicants who have an unencumbered license from another state or country to practice registered nursing or licensed practical nursing, a waiver of the initial licensure requirement to take the national licensure examination in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §8-307, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“English language competency examination” means an examination that tests an individual’s written and oral competency in the English language.

“Geriatric nursing assistant” means a certified nursing assistant who has successfully completed the requirements for geriatric nursing assistant mandated under federal law and the regulations of the Board.
“Former licensee” means an individual who once had an active license with the Board who is no longer active.

“Multistate licensure privilege” means an authorization to practice registered nursing or licensed practical nursing in Maryland that is granted to a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse who has an active multistate license issued by another state in accordance with the Nurse Licensure Compact.
“NCLEX” means the National Council Licensure Examination for initial licensure as a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse.
“Nursing assistant” means either:
A certified nursing assistant; or
A geriatric nursing assistant.
“Preceptor” means a registered nurse who meets the qualifications of faculty as described in Regulation .16 of this chapter.
“Preceptorship” means an individualized refresher course approved by the Board and offered by an institution employing nurses which complies with Regulation .16 of this chapter.
“Student” means a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse who is required to complete a refresher course in order to maintain or reestablish an active license.
“Substantially equivalent” has the meaning stated in §§C and D of this regulation.
“Volunteer” means a licensee who, at the time of licensure renewal, elects to receive a license which only allows the licensee to provide professional services without remuneration.
“Written and oral competency in the English language” means the ability to demonstrate proficiency in listening, reading, speaking, and writing the English language.
“Substantially equivalent” means a registered nursing or licensed practical nursing education program that:

Contains theoretical learning experiences and related clinical learning experiences that include direct patient care within various settings consistent with program objectives, outcomes, or competencies conducted either concurrently with or after the theoretical learning experience; and
Meets the curriculum requirements for Maryland schools of nursing at the time of the applicant’s graduation, including, but not limited to:
The appropriate level of the graduate's intended scope of practice;
Didactic and clinical learning experiences that are diverse and consistent with program objectives, outcomes, or competencies;
Didactic and clinical instruction in nursing care of families and clients throughout the life span in a variety of care settings requiring nursing measures appropriate for:
The maintenance or restoration of mental and physical health;
Preventive, rehabilitative, and curative aspects of health care;
Biophysical, psychosocial, cultural, and spiritual components of health and illness; and
Professional issues content; and
Didactic and clinical instructional content that includes, but is not limited to, the areas of:
Medical and surgical nursing;
Maternal and child health;
Psychiatric nursing; and
Geriatric nursing.

“Substantially equivalent” does not mean a registered nurse or licensed practical nursing education program in another state or country that does not have a supervised clinical learning experience requirement.
Registered nurses or licensed practical nurses who hold a current active license in any other state or jurisdiction may render nursing care:
For not more than 30 days, to an individual who is visiting the State for medical, educational, or personal reasons;
For the purpose of the interstate transport and care of patients traveling to and from Maryland; and
During an emergency situation.

A registered nurse or licensed practical nurse who holds a multistate licensure privilege under the Nurse Licensure Compact may practice nursing in this State in accordance with the laws of this State.
Nursing Graduate.
A nursing graduate is a graduate of:
A Board-approved registered nursing or licensed practical nursing education program; or
An out-of-state nursing education program determined to be equivalent by the Board.
A nursing graduate may practice as set forth in §C(5)—(7) of this regulation if:
The nursing graduate has an application for a license pending before the Board; and
One of the following circumstances exists:
The nursing graduate has not taken the NCLEX examination;
The nursing graduate has taken the NCLEX examination, but the results of the NCLEX examination are not yet known;
The nursing graduate has taken and passed the NCLEX examination but is waiting for the completion of the criminal history records check; or

The nursing graduate has taken and failed the NCLEX examination but has not failed the NCLEX examination more than one time within the 120 day period immediately following the submission of the application to the Board.
A nursing graduate shall cease practice as a nursing graduate:
No later than 120 days after the date the nursing graduate submitted an application to the Board; or
Immediately if the nursing graduate fails the second NCLEX examination.

If the nursing graduate fails the NCLEX examination, the nursing graduate may practice as a nursing assistant provided the individual obtains certification as a nursing assistant and practices according to COMAR 10.39.01.
A nursing graduate shall:
Practice only under the direct supervision of a registered nurse who is physically present on the unit to:
Cosign medication transcription, medication administration, and nursing documentation; and
Continually observe, assist, coordinate, evaluate, and monitor the nursing graduate; and
Use the initials "NG" after the nursing graduate's name as credentials.

After successful completion of an organized staff development program which includes an evaluation that the nursing graduate is competent and in compliance with §C(5) of this regulation, the nursing graduate may:
Transcribe medication orders if:
Written policies and procedures are available on the unit of care; and
An organized staff development program which includes skill validation has been successfully completed by the nursing graduate;
After competency has been validated by the facility:
Administer medications and controlled substances; and
Sign controlled substances sheets;
Document in the medical record with the abbreviation "NG";
Perform patient assessments after the initial assessment or after the first assessment of the shift performed by the registered nurse; and
Perform and document routine procedures taught within the nursing graduate's generic nursing program, including but not limited to:
Placing nasal gastric tubes;
Performing urinary catheterizations;
Applying sterile dressings;
Performing blood sugar checks; and
Obtaining specimens.
A nursing graduate may not:
Work without the physical presence of and direct supervision by a registered nurse;
Refer to oneself or practice as a registered nurse (RN) or licensed practical nurse (LPN);
Be considered a staff person for purposes of a staffing pattern;
Accept charge responsibilities; or

Perform initial patient assessment or the first patient assessment of a shift, develop patient plans of care, evaluate or document patient discharge, or independently administer medications or intravenous therapy.
The Board shall reinstate the license of a former licensee who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the former licensee meets the renewal requirements.

After January 1, 2010, an applicant for reinstatement who has failed to renew the applicant's license for a period of 1 year or more shall submit to a criminal history records check before the license is reinstated.
Temporary License.
The Board shall issue a temporary license to a former licensee who:
Applies for reinstatement in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §8-313, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Meets the renewal requirements of Health Occupations Article, §8-312, Annotated Code of Maryland; and
Is awaiting the completion of the criminal history records check.
The temporary license issued pursuant to §C(1) of this regulation is effective until the earlier of 90 days after the date of issue or the date the Board issues an active license.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“ACME” means the Accreditation Commission for Midwifery Education.
“ACNM” means the American College of Nurse Midwives.
“Advanced practice registered nurse (APRN)” means a registered nurse who is certified by the Board as:
A certified nurse midwife (CNM);
A certified registered nurse anesthetist (CRNA);
A certified nurse practitioner (CRNP); or
A clinical nurse specialist (CNS).
“AMCB” means the American Midwifery Certification Board.
“Board” means the Board of Nursing.
“Certification” means the permission to practice nurse midwifery granted by the Board to a registered nurse who has:
Met all the specified requirements of a national certifying body recognized by the Board; and
Complied with the requirements of this chapter.
“Certified nurse midwife” means an advanced practice registered nurse who is certified by the Board to practice nurse midwifery in this State.
“Clinical practice guidelines” standards for practice of midwifery using current guidelines established by ACNM in Standards for the Practice of Midwifery.

“Delegated medical functions” means those functions that come within the definition of “practice medicine” in the Health Occupations Article, §14-101, Annotated Code of Maryland, that have been delegated to a certified nurse midwife to perform.
“Multistate licensure privilege” has the meaning set forth in COMAR 10.27.01.01B.
“Newborn” means an infant in the first 28 days after birth.
“Nurse midwifery” means the health care management of newborns and clients throughout their reproductive life cycle.
“Physician” means an individual licensed to practice medicine in this State.
“Registered nurse (RN)” means an individual who:
Is licensed by the Board to practice registered nursing; or
Has a multistate licensure privilege to practice registered nursing.
A certified nurse midwife who meets the requirements of Regulation .02 of this chapter may perform the following functions:
Independent management of clients appropriate to the skill and educational preparation of the certified nurse midwife and the nurse midwife's clinical practice guidelines;
Consult or collaborate with a physician or other health care provider as needed; and
Refer clients with complications beyond the scope of practice of the certified nurse midwife to a licensed physician.
A certified nurse midwife shall keep a record of all cases attended and maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A certified nurse midwife has the right and obligation to refuse to perform any delegated medical act, oral or written, if, in the certified nurse midwife’s judgment, it is unsafe or an invalidly prescribed medical act or beyond the competence of the certified nurse midwife, in which case the nurse midwife shall notify the delegating physician at once.
A certified nurse midwife shall comply with applicable State and federal law.

para.text: A nurse anesthetist shall collaborate with an anesthesiologist, licensed physician, or dentist in the following manner:
An anesthesiologist, licensed physician, or dentist shall be physically available to the nurse anesthetist for consultation at all times during the administration of, and recovery from, anesthesia;
An anesthesiologist shall be available for consultation to the nurse anesthetist for other aspects of the practice of nurse anesthesia; and
If an anesthesiologist is not available, a licensed physician or dentist shall be available to provide this type of consultation.
The nurse anesthetist shall assure that a qualified anesthesia provider:
Performs a thorough and complete preanesthetic assessment;
Obtains informed consent for the planned anesthetic intervention from the patient or responsible other; and
Formulates a patient-specific plan for anesthesia care.
The nurse anesthetist as part of the standards of practice shall:
Implement and adjust the anesthesia care plan as needed to adapt to the patient's response to the anesthesia;
Monitor the patient's physiologic condition for untoward identifiable reactions and initiate appropriate corrective actions as required;
Enter prompt, complete, and accurate documentation of pertinent information on the patient's record;
Transfer responsibility for care of the patient to other qualified providers in a manner which assures continuity of care and patient safety;
Ensure that appropriate safety precautions are taken to minimize the risks of fire, explosion, electrical shock, and equipment malfunction;
Maintain appropriate infection control standards;
Evaluate anesthesia care to assure its quality;
Maintain continual competence in anesthesia practice;
Respect and maintain the basic rights of patients; and
Maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Nurse Practitioner — Scope and Standards of Practice.

para.text: A nurse practitioner may independently perform the following functions:
A comprehensive physical assessment of patients;
In accordance with Family Law Article, §2-301, Annotated Code of Maryland, certify to the clerk of the court that a:
16 or 17 year old individual, who wants to get married without parental consent, has been examined and found to be pregnant or has given birth to a child; or
15 year old individual, who has parental consent to be married, has been examined and found to be pregnant or has given birth to a child;
In accordance with Transportation Article, §13-704, Annotated Code of Maryland, certify to the Department of Transportation that an individual needs special consideration for certain health reasons;
In accordance with Health-General Article, §4-208, Annotated Code of Maryland, complete the date of birth and medical information required on a birth certificate;
In accordance with Health-General Article, §4-212, Annotated Code of Maryland, complete a death certificate if:
The medical examiner does not take charge of the body; and
The deceased was under the care of the nurse practitioner;
Establish medical diagnosis for common short-term and chronic stable health problems;
In accordance with Health-General Article, §4-212, Annotated Code of Maryland, file a replacement death certificate;
In accordance with Health-General Article, §5-601, Annotated Code of Maryland, issue a do not resuscitate order on a Maryland Emergency Medical Services form.
Order, perform, and interpret laboratory and diagnostic tests;
Order and perform diagnostic, therapeutic, and corrective measures;
Prescribe drugs;
Provide emergency care;
Refer patients to appropriate licensed physicians or other health care providers as needed;
In accordance with COMAR 20.31.03.01, certify that the utility client has a serious illness or the need for life-support equipment; and
In accordance with Health-General Article, §5-602, Annotated Code of Maryland, witness an advance directive.
A psychiatric nurse practitioner together with a physician is authorized to sign applications:
In accordance with Health-General Article, §10-615, Annotated Code of Maryland, to admit a minor to a facility for treatment of a mental disorder; and
In accordance with Health-General Article, §10-616, Annotated Code of Maryland, to admit an individual on an involuntary basis to a facility for treatment of a mental disorder.
A nurse practitioner may practice only in the area of specialization in which certified.
Nothing in this chapter limits or prohibits a registered nurse from performing those functions which constitute the practice of registered nursing as defined by law.
A nurse practitioner has a right and obligation to refuse to perform any delegated act, oral or written, if in the nurse practitioner's judgment it is unsafe or an invalidly prescribed medical act.
An individual certified under this chapter shall be subject to disciplinary sanctions set forth in Health Occupations Article, §8-316, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A nurse practitioner shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
A nurse practitioner may personally prepare and dispense any drug that a nurse practitioner is authorized to prescribe in the course of treating a patient at:
A medical facility or clinic that specializes in the treatment of medical cases reimbursable through workers' compensation insurance;
A medical facility or clinic that is operated on a nonprofit basis;
A health center that operates on a campus of an institution of higher education;
A public health facility, a medical facility under contract with a State or local health department, or a facility funded with public funds; or
A nonprofit hospital or a nonprofit hospital out-patient facility as authorized under the policies established by the hospital.
A nurse practitioner who personally prepares and dispenses a drug in the course of treating a patient shall:
Comply with the labeling requirements of Health Occupations Article, §12-505, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Record the dispensing of the prescription drug on the patient's chart;
Allow the Division of Drug Control to enter and inspect the nurse practitioner's office at all reasonable hours;
Except for starter dosages or samples dispensed without charge, provide the patient with a written prescription; and
Stamp all Schedule III, IV, and V prescriptions with the letter "C" in red ink, not less than 1 inch high in the lower right hand corner.
A nurse practitioner shall:
Maintain two separate files, one for Schedule II prescriptions and another file for all other prescriptions; and
Maintain all prescription files for 7 years.
A nurse practitioner may personally prepare and dispense a starter dosage of any drug the nurse practitioner is authorized to prescribe. The nurse practitioner shall:
Label the starter dosage in compliance with the labeling requirements of Health Occupations Article, §12-505, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Provide the starter dose free of charge; and
Enter the starter dose dispensed in the patient's medical record.

para.text: Assessment.
The RN shall collect client health data.
Measurement Criteria.
Data collection shall involve the client, family, significant others, other members of the health care team, and the health record, when appropriate.
Data may include the following dimensions:
Physical;
Psychological;
Sociocultural;
Spiritual;
Cognitive;
Functional abilities;
Developmental;
Economic;
Technology; and
Life-style.
Priority of data collection is determined by the client's immediate condition or needs, health status, and setting.
Pertinent data shall be collected using appropriate assessment techniques.
Data collection shall include a technology assessment.
The data collection process shall be comprehensive, systematic, and ongoing.
Relevant health status data, including changes, shall be documented in an authorized record which is accessible and in a retrievable form.
Analysis and Nursing Diagnosis.
The RN shall analyze the assessment data in determining nursing diagnoses.
Measurement Criteria.
The RN shall analyze the data, consider the options, including technology, and make a determination as to whether the selected options are appropriate for the needs of the client.
Nursing diagnoses shall be:
Derived in a complete, systematic, and ongoing manner from the assessment data;
Validated with the client, family, significant others, and other members of the health care team, when possible; and
Documented in a manner that facilitates the determination of expected outcomes and plan of care.
Nursing diagnoses shall identify the nature and extent of the client's health status, capabilities, and limitations.
Outcome Identification.
The RN shall identify expected outcomes individualized to the client.
Measurement Criteria.
Outcomes shall be:
Derived in a comprehensive, systematic, and ongoing manner from the diagnoses;
Directed toward management of the client's health problems;
Formulated with the client, family, significant other, or other members of the health care team, when possible and appropriate;
Culturally appropriate and realistic in relation to the client's present and potential capabilities;
Attainable in relation to the resources available to the client;
Documented as measurable goals with time estimates for attainment as appropriate; and
Documented in an authorized record which is accessible and in a retrievable form.
Outcomes provide direction for continuity of care.
Planning.
The RN shall develop a plan of care that prescribes interventions to attain expected outcomes.
Measurement Criteria.
The plan shall be:
Individualized in a comprehensive, systematic and ongoing manner;
Developed utilizing available data;
Prioritized to meet the client's condition or needs;
Developed, coordinated, and communicated with the client, family, significant other, and other members of the health care team as appropriate;
Congruent with the client's therapeutic regime; and
Documented.
The plan shall:
Reflect current nursing practice;
Provide for continuity of care; and
Include identification, coordination, and utilization of available resources.
Implementation.
The RN shall implement the interventions identified in the plan of care.
Measurement Criteria.
Interventions shall be:
Implemented recognizing the rights of the client, the family, and significant others;
Consistent with the established plan of care;
Implemented in a competent, safe, and appropriate manner consistent with knowledge of scientific principles; and
Documented.
Interventions may include, but are not limited to:
Patient teaching;
Counseling;
Implementing clinical practice guidelines, protocols, and pathways; and
Independent nursing functions.
Selected interventions may be assigned and delegated to other personnel participating in delivering care.
When assignment or delegation occurs, supervision is provided.
A safe and therapeutic environment is provided for the delivery of nursing care.

Relevant information which may be needed to carry out the nursing plan is provided to the client, family, significant others, and other members of the health care team without violating the client's confidentiality.
Evaluation.
The RN shall evaluate the client's progress toward attainment of outcomes.
Measurement Criteria.
Evaluation shall be systematic, ongoing, and criterion-based.
The client, family, significant other, and other members of the health care team shall be involved in the evaluation process, when appropriate.
Ongoing assessment data shall be used to evaluate the process of care and to revise the nursing diagnosis, outcomes, and the plan of care.
Revisions of diagnoses, outcomes, and the plan of care shall be documented.
The effectiveness of interventions shall be evaluated in relation to outcomes.
The responses to interventions shall be documented and communicated to the client and other members of the health care team.
The RN charged with the documentation of the client's discharge shall make the final nursing evaluation.
Documentation. The RN shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: In a team relationship the licensed practical nurse contributes to the nursing process. The nursing process shall include, but is not limited to, the following elements listed in §B—C of this regulation.
Nursing Assessment. The LPN contributes to the nursing assessment by:
Collecting data for the assessment of the client:
Through direct observation;
From interviews with the client, client’s family, and significant others;
From the review of the client’s medical records including, but not limited to:
Past history;
Laboratory studies;
Medications; and
Consultations; and
By assessing the environment;
Performing a focused nursing assessment of the client’s current conditions and problems or needs which includes:
The nursing interview;
A physical assessment;
The client’s common predictable, chronic, routine, recurrent health problems; and
Identification of any changes in the client’s symptoms and behavior;
Communicating the assessment on records that reflect:
Changes in the client’s health status; and
A continuous collection of data by updating and revising of the nursing assessment; and
Data recorded in a manner which is:
Complete, timely, and accurate;
Consistent with general standards of nursing practice; and
Consistent with the facility’s policies and procedures.
Nursing Plan of Care.
Development. The LPN contributes to the development of the nursing plan of care by:
Reporting ongoing data collection;
Reporting changes that include, but are not limited to, the client’s;
Condition;
Changed goals; and
Changed priorities;
Making recommendations to individualize interventions specific to the client;
Reporting communication with;
The client;
The client’s family;
Significant others; and
Other members of the health care team; and
Documenting in appropriate records.
Implementation. The LPN participates in the implementation of the nursing plan of care by:
Continuing to collect and report data;
Assisting in the coordination of client care with other health care team members as directed by the RN;
Implementing standardized or RN developed teaching plans under the direction of the RN;
Contributing to the nursing case management by:
Implementing assigned components of the nursing care plan; and
Continuing to collect and report data regarding the implemented plan including the client’s response to intervention and problem identification;
Contributing to nursing management and supervision of the certified nursing assistant and unlicensed personnel by:
Assuring nursing functions are performed competently and timely; and
Reporting to the leader of the nursing team; and
In accordance with the nursing team’s plan of care for the client and with COMAR10.27.11, delegating acts of the LPN’s practice to:
The certified nursing assistant;
The certified medication technician; and
Unlicensed personnel;
Performing nursing interventions in a competent safe manner appropriate to the LPN’s scope of practice including:
Administration of medications and treatments;
Administration of infusion therapy consistent with COMAR 10.27.20; and
Nursing intervention consistent with any declaratory rulings and regulations issued by the Board;
Documenting implementation of nursing care timely, completely, and accurately; and
Utilizing identified nursing approaches which include, but are not limited to:
Reflecting knowledge of scientific principles;
Recognizing the rights of the client, the client’s family, and significant others; and
Providing a safe and therapeutic environment.
Evaluation. The LPN contributes to the evaluation of the nursing plan of care by:
Collecting and communicating data on the client’s goal achievement;
Assisting in identifying barriers to the client’s meeting any identified goal;
Reporting to other members of the health care team in a timely, accurate, and complete manner on data collected from;
The client;
The client’s family;
Significant others; and
Other health care providers;
Assisting in evaluating the client’s competency in performing any treatment and self administering medication by utilizing established competency based evaluation tools;
Making recommendations regarding modification of the teaching nursing plan based on the client’s response;
Making recommendations regarding any revision to the nursing plan of care; and
Documenting the evaluation data on appropriate records.
Nursing Team Relationship.
The LPN as a part of the nursing team:
Functions as a team member under the leadership of the RN who is the team leader;
Participates in providing care for the client; and
Provides care for the client to the fullest extent allowed by the LPN’s scope of practice.

Each licensed nurse has responsibility for oversight or supervision of nursing practice appropriate to his or her level of licensure which includes critically watching, instructing, directing, and evaluating anothers nursing practice.
Documentation. The LPN shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

The RN-WCCM shall comply with all:
Other statutes or regulations governing registered nurse practice; and
Laws, statutory policies, and procedures of the Commission.
The RN-WCCM shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: The licensee shall comply with the employer's written policies and procedures which are in compliance with this chapter regarding infusion therapy.
The licensee shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: An RN-FNE may perform the following tasks and functions with respect to the age group for which the RN-FNE is certified under Regulation .03 of this chapter:
Perform forensic evidentiary examinations on victims and alleged perpetrators in connection with physical, sexual, or domestic assaults, whether chronic or acute;

Before the forensic evidentiary examination, obtain consent from the individual being examined, from the parent or guardian of a minor individual, or from the proper authority for photographing and evidence collection;
Prepare and document the assault history interview;
Perform the forensic evidentiary physical assessment, which may include use of an ALS;
Complete the physical evidence kit provided by law enforcement;
Gather, preserve, handle, document, and label forensic evidence, including but not limited to:
Labeling evidence collection containers with the patient's identifying data per local jurisdiction requirements;
Placing evidence in the evidence collection container and sealing the container;
Signing the evidence collection container as the collector of the evidence;
Taking photographs; and
Obtaining swabs, smears, and hair and body fluid samples;
Maintain the chain of custody;
Provide immediate health interventions using clinical practice guidelines;
Obtain consultations and make referrals to health care personnel and community agencies;
Provide immediate crisis intervention at the time of the examination;
Provide discharge instructions;
Participate in forensic proceedings including courtroom testimony;
Interface with law enforcement officials, crime labs, and State attorney's offices; and
Assist the licensed physician in performing a forensic evidentiary examination.
Clinical Practice Guidelines. An RN-FNE may practice only in a clinical setting in which clinical policy and practice guidelines:
Have been approved by the facility's medical and nursing departments;
Designate the availability of qualified physician resources;
Identify the department in which an RN-FNE shall function; and
Designate a program coordinator who has experience in forensic evidentiary examinations to administer the RN-FNE training program.
The program coordinator:
Is responsible for obtaining Board approval of the curriculum before conducting a training program;
Has responsibility for oversight and administration of the facility’s RN-FNE training program and the practice of the facility’s RN-FNEs;
Verifies the qualifications and certifications of any RN-FNE practicing in the facility;
Administers and manages the RN-FNE practice;
Approves practice protocols and standards of care for RN-FNE practice;
Shall develop a peer review process that includes, but is not limited to:
Coordinating the peer review of cases;
Ensuring that the peer review is consistent with the standardized data collection process;
Ensuring that a peer reviewer meets the qualifications in Regulation .05 of this chapter; and
Using the standardized form for peer review that is required by the Board;
Interfaces with law enforcement, the State's attorney, and community resource groups;
Implements the facility's Board-approved RN-FNE curricula; and
Facilitates reimbursement for RN-FNE services by cooperating with the facility's billing department and interacting with the State reimbursement system.
An RN-FNE shall comply with all State and federal statutes and regulations related to the RN-FNE practice.
An RN-FNE shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: The nurse shall comply with the employment settings written cosmetic policies and procedures that comply with this chapter.
The nurse shall be guided by and comply with the written policies and procedures in keeping with recognized standards of care that include, but are not limited to:
Care and maintenance of appropriate equipment and safe operation;
Description of how the procedure is to be performed;
Education;
Assessment;
Emergency procedures;
Monitoring guidelines;
Operator and safety when utilizing equipment;
A continuous quality improvement process which includes, but is not limited to:
Unexpected outcomes;
Side effects; and
Complications;
Obtaining or ensuring that the client’s informed consent has been obtained that documents the patient’s awareness that it is the licensed nurse who will perform the cosmetic procedure; and
Documenting the performance of the cosmetic procedure including, but not limited to:
Patient response;
Patient education; and
Safety precautions taken on behalf of the patient.
The nurse may perform the identified cosmetic procedure when there is a completed prescriptive order from an authorized prescriber that includes, but is not limited to:
The procedure to be performed;
Identification of the specific treatment area;
Identification of medication, dosage, route, and time interval for administration of the medication for the specific cosmetic procedure;
Identification of the light source and the radio frequency, current dosage, intensity, and time period it is to be applied; and
The use of any topical anesthetic.
Before a nurse performs any of these cosmetic procedures, the authorized prescriber shall:
Complete an initial assessment and evaluation of the patient before the procedure is performed;
Develop a treatment plan for the specific patient;
Be physically present in the setting; and
Be immediately available:
At the time the procedure is performed; and
Post-treatment to evaluate the patient.
The nurse shall maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: An electrologist shall be primarily concerned with the welfare of the patient.

An electrologist shall seek professional treatment and refrain from the practice of electrology, if the electrologist suffers from a physical, mental, emotional, or chemical impairment which negatively impacts the electrologist's ability to practice electrology.
An electrologist shall:
Use professional discretion and integrity in relationships with other members of the health care community;
Engage in professional conduct at all times, with honesty, integrity, self-respect, and fairness;
Remain free from conflicts of interest, fulfill the objectives, and maintain the integrity of the electrology profession;
Provide accurate fee information to:
Patients;
Individuals responsible for payment for treatment; and
Insurers;
Respect a patient's dignity, autonomy, and privacy; and

Practice electrology only as defined in the scope of practice set forth in Health Occupations Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland, and remain in compliance with all federal, State, and local laws governing the practice of electrology.
Relationships with Patients. An electrologist shall:
Use professional judgment in evaluation and treatment procedures;
Make a full disclosure to each patient who cannot reasonably be expected to benefit from treatment;
Terminate a professional relationship with a patient in an appropriate manner;
Upon termination:
Provide the patient with sufficient notice to permit the patient to obtain the services of another professional; and
If appropriate, assist the patient by providing referrals;
Maintain written records of a patient under the electrologist's care for at least 7 years after termination of treatment;
Make a patient's records available to the patient upon request, complying with applicable laws for disclosure of medical records;
Arrange for another professional to provide for the needs of patients during anticipated absences when the electrologist would be unavailable to patients;
Accurately inform patients, other health care professionals, and the public of the limitations of the practice of electrology;
Adequately assess each patient before beginning treatment to determine if contraindications against treatment exist; and
Exercise independent professional judgment in the treatment or evaluation, or both, of patients, regardless of whether the patient was referred by another health care provider.
Records, Confidentiality, and Informed Consent. An electrologist shall:
Respect and maintain the privacy and confidentiality of each patient;
Disclose patient records or information about a patient only with the patient's consent or as required by law;
Adequately safeguard confidential patient information, and properly store and dispose of records;
Provide sufficient information to a patient to allow the patient to make informed decisions regarding treatment, including:
The purpose and nature of any evaluation or treatment regimen;
Alternatives to treatment;
Side effects and benefits of any treatment regimen proposed and alternatives to that treatment;
The estimated cost of treatment;
The right of the patient to withdraw from treatment at any time, as well as the risks associated with withdrawing from treatment;

The patient's right to decline to participate in treatment if any aspect of the treatment will be recorded, documented, photographed, observed, or otherwise used in any educational or other program; and
Participating in research programs only if the programs comply with federal and State laws and only under the following conditions:
Informed consent of the patient is obtained;
There is no direct or implied penalty for the patient's refusal to participate; and
The patient's autonomy and dignity are respected.
Maintain medical records in accordance with Health-General Article, Title 4, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Treatment.
An electrologist may not perform treatments or provide services which:
The electrologist is not qualified to perform; or
Are beyond the scope of the electrologist's education, training, capabilities, experience, and scope of practice.
An electrologist shall obtain additional training, information, and supervision as needed:
To perform a new electrology technique or service in a new specialty area; or
To employ a new treatment modality.
An electrologist shall maintain current licensure to practice electrology and satisfy continuing education requirements established by the Board.

para.text: Criminal History Record Information.

Upon receipt of an applicant’s criminal history records information in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §20-303, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Board shall consider the following factors in determining whether to grant a certificate:
The age at which the crime was committed;
The circumstances surrounding the crime;
The length of time that has passed since the crime;
Subsequent work history;
Employment and character references; and
Other evidence that demonstrates whether the applicant poses a threat to the public health or safety.
The Board may not issue a certificate if the criminal history record information required under Health Occupations Article, §20-303, Annotated Code of Maryland, has not been received.
Upon review of a completed application, the Board shall:
Notify the applicant that the applicant is:
Approved for certification; and
Qualified to take the examination; or
Deny certification.
Denial of Applications.
The Board may deny certification if the applicant has:
Not completed the academic and experience requirements in Regulation .02 of this chapter;
Failed the examination requirements in Regulation .03 of this chapter;
Failed to remit a fee;
Failed to properly complete the application form;
Violated Health Occupations Article, Title 20, Annotated Code of Maryland, or any provision of this subtitle; or
Been shown to have a lack of good moral character.
If the Board denies certification under §E(1)(e) or (f) of this regulation, the Board or the Board's designee shall:
Provide the applicant written notification of the Board's intent to deny and the basis for that denial; and
Notify the applicant of the applicant's right to request a formal hearing to appeal the denial.
An applicant whose certification has been denied may reapply and shall submit with the new application proof of compliance with:
This subtitle; and
Health Occupations Article, Title 20, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Issuance of Certificate.
If the Board approves an applicant for certification and the applicant passes the State Standards Examination, the Board shall:
Send the applicant a notice specifying that the applicant has qualified for a certificate; and
Issue a certificate, available online, to the applicant.
The Board shall include on each certificate the:
Full name of the certificate holder; and
Serial number assigned by the Board.

Unless the Board suspends or revokes the certificate, the certification is effective for up to 2 years from the date issued and authorizes the individual to administer a residential child care program.

At least 1 month before the certificate expires, the Board shall send to the certified program administrator, by electronic means or first-class mail to the last known electronic or physical address, a renewal notice that states:
The date on which the current certificate expires;
The date by which the renewal application shall be received by the Board for the renewal to be issued; and
The amount of the renewal fee.
The Board shall renew the certificate of a certified program administrator who:
Otherwise is entitled to obtain a certificate;
Pays to the Board a renewal fee set by the Board; and
Submits to the Board:
A renewal application on a form that the Board requires;
Satisfactory evidence of compliance with any continuing education and other qualifications and requirements set by the Board.
Unless waived by the Board in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §20-310(f), Annotated Code of Maryland, evidence of application for a child protective services background clearance; and
Evidence of having submitted to a State and national criminal history records check conducted by the Central Repository.
Criminal History Record Information.

Upon receipt of an applicant’s criminal history records information in accordance with Health Occupations Article, §20-303, Annotated Code of Maryland, the Board shall consider the following factors in determining whether to grant a certificate:
The age at which the crime was committed;
The circumstances surrounding the crime;
The length of time that has passed since the crime;
Subsequent work history;
Employment and character references; and
Other evidence that demonstrates whether the applicant poses a threat to the public health or safety.
The Board may not issue a certificate if the criminal history record information required under Health Occupations Article, §20-303, Annotated Code of Maryland, has not been received.

section.heading: Duplicate or Corrected Certificate.
section.text: The Board shall issue a duplicate certificate, electronically, to the certificate holder if:

para.text: The certificate holder has a change of name and does the following:
Makes the request to the Board in writing on the form provided by the Board; and
Provides appropriate legal documentation of the change; or
The Board, as a result of its error, issues an incorrect certificate and the certificate holder:
Notifies the Board in writing within 6 weeks of discovery of the incorrect certificate; or

Does not receive electronic verification of the certificate within 6 weeks of issuance and provides a statement to the Board attesting to the unavailability of the certificate online within 4 months of the date the certificate was issued by the Board.
